questions.question: She __________ (write) an excellent essay last week.
questions.explanation: The action happened last week, so the correct form is 'wrote' in the past simple tense.

questions.question: They __________ (not go) to the concert yesterday.
questions.explanation: The action is negative and happened yesterday, so 'didn't go' is the correct form in the past simple tense.

questions.question: He __________ (finish) his homework before dinner.
questions.explanation: The action happened before dinner, so the correct form is 'finished' in the past simple tense.

questions.question: We __________ (see) a wonderful movie last night.
questions.explanation: The action happened last night, so 'saw' is the correct form in the past simple tense.

questions.question: The team __________ (win) the championship last year.
questions.explanation: The action happened last year, so 'won' is the correct form in the past simple tense.

questions.question: She __________ (not meet) him at the party.
questions.explanation: The action is negative and happened at the party, so 'didn't meet' is the correct form in the past simple tense.

questions.question: I __________ (buy) a new car last month.
questions.explanation: The action happened last month, so 'bought' is the correct form in the past simple tense.

questions.question: You __________ (not tell) me about the meeting.
questions.explanation: The action is negative and supposed to have happened already, so 'didn't tell' is the correct form in the past simple tense.

questions.question: She __________ (arrive) late for the appointment.
questions.explanation: The action happened already, so 'arrived' is the correct form in the past simple tense.

questions.question: We __________ (decide) to move to a new city.
questions.explanation: The action has been done, so 'decided' is the correct form in the past simple tense.

questions.question: While I __________ (read), the phone rang.
questions.explanation: The action of reading was in progress when the phone rang, so 'was reading' is the correct form in the past continuous tense.

questions.question: They __________ (watch) TV when I arrived.
questions.explanation: The action of watching TV was ongoing when I arrived, so 'were watching' is the correct form in the past continuous tense.

questions.question: He __________ (work) on his project all night.
questions.explanation: The action of working was ongoing all night, so 'was working' is the correct form in the past continuous tense.

questions.question: I __________ (not listen) to music when you called.
questions.explanation: The action of not listening was ongoing when you called, so 'wasn't listening' is the correct form in the past continuous tense.

questions.question: We __________ (have) dinner when the lights went out.
questions.explanation: The action of having dinner was ongoing when the lights went out, so 'were having' is the correct form in the past continuous tense.

questions.question: She __________ (write) an email when the computer crashed.
questions.explanation: The action of writing an email was ongoing when the computer crashed, so 'was writing' is the correct form in the past continuous tense.

questions.question: They __________ (play) football when it started to rain.
questions.explanation: The action of playing football was ongoing when it started to rain, so 'were playing' is the correct form in the past continuous tense.

questions.question: I __________ (study) for the exam all evening.
questions.explanation: The action of studying was ongoing all evening, so 'was studying' is the correct form in the past continuous tense.

questions.question: He __________ (not sleep) when the alarm went off.
questions.explanation: The action of not sleeping was ongoing when the alarm went off, so 'wasn't sleeping' is the correct form in the past continuous tense.

questions.question: We __________ (talk) about the issue when she interrupted.
questions.explanation: The action of talking was ongoing when she interrupted, so 'were talking' is the correct form in the past continuous tense.

questions.question: By the time we arrived, the movie __________ (start).
questions.explanation: The action of the movie starting happened before we arrived, so 'had started' is the correct form in the past perfect tense.

questions.question: She __________ (finish) her homework before she went out.
questions.explanation: The action of finishing homework happened before she went out, so 'had finished' is the correct form in the past perfect tense.

questions.question: He didn't go to the party because he __________ (not receive) an invitation.
questions.explanation: The action of not receiving an invitation happened before he decided not to go, so 'had not received' is the correct form in the past perfect tense.

questions.question: They __________ (already leave) when we got there.
questions.explanation: The action of leaving happened before we got there, so 'had already left' is the correct form in the past perfect tense.

questions.question: She couldn't find her keys because she __________ (lose) them.
questions.explanation: The action of losing the keys happened before she couldn't find them, so 'had lost' is the correct form in the past perfect tense.

questions.question: We __________ (not see) such a beautiful sunset before.
questions.explanation: The action of not seeing such a sunset happened before the time being referred to, so 'had not seen' is the correct form in the past perfect tense.

questions.question: After they __________ (eat) dinner, they went for a walk.
questions.explanation: The action of eating dinner happened before they went for a walk, so 'had eaten' is the correct form in the past perfect tense.

questions.question: She __________ (never be) to Paris before her trip last year.
questions.explanation: The action of never being to Paris happened before her trip last year, so 'had never been' is the correct form in the past perfect tense.

questions.question: By the time I got to the station, the train __________ (leave).
questions.explanation: The action of the train leaving happened before I got to the station, so 'had left' is the correct form in the past perfect tense.

questions.question: He __________ (save) enough money before he bought the car.
questions.explanation: The action of saving enough money happened before he bought the car, so 'had saved' is the correct form in the past perfect tense.

questions.question: Choose the passive voice form of the sentence: 'The chef prepares the meal.'

options.a: The meal is prepared by the chef.
options.b: The meal prepares by the chef.
options.c: The chef is prepared by the meal.
options.d: The meal was preparing by the chef.

questions.explanation: In passive voice, the object of the active sentence becomes the subject, and the verb form changes accordingly.

questions.question: Choose the active voice form of the sentence: 'The novel was written by the author.'

options.d: The novel is writing the author.

questions.explanation: In active voice, the subject performs the action, so the author is the one who wrote the novel.

questions.question: Choose the passive voice form of the sentence: 'They will finish the project next week.'

options.a: The project will be finished next week.
options.b: The project will be finishing next week.
options.c: The project will finish next week.
options.d: The project is finished next week.

questions.explanation: In passive voice for future tense, 'will be' is used with the past participle of the verb.

questions.question: Choose the active voice form of the sentence: 'A masterpiece is being painted by the artist.'

options.c: The artist is painting a masterpiece.
options.d: A masterpiece is painting the artist.

questions.explanation: In active voice, the subject (the artist) is performing the action of painting.

questions.question: Choose the passive voice form of the sentence: 'Someone stole my bike.'
questions.explanation: In passive voice, the object (my bike) becomes the subject, and the past participle 'stolen' is used.

questions.question: Choose the passive voice form of the sentence: 'The company has launched a new product.'

options.a: A new product has been launched by the company.
options.b: A new product is launched by the company.
options.c: A new product launches by the company.
options.d: A new product is launching by the company.

questions.explanation: In passive voice for present perfect, 'has been' is used with the past participle.

questions.question: Choose the active voice form of the sentence: 'The homework was completed by the students.'

options.d: The homework is completing the students.

questions.explanation: In active voice, the subject (the students) is performing the action of completing.

questions.question: Choose the passive voice form of the sentence: 'They are going to build a new bridge.'

options.a: A new bridge is going to be built.
options.b: A new bridge is going to be build.
options.c: A new bridge is going to build.

questions.explanation: In passive voice for future plans, 'is going to be' is used with the past participle.

questions.question: Choose the active voice form of the sentence: 'The cake was baked by Mary.'
questions.explanation: In active voice, the subject (Mary) is performing the action of baking.

questions.question: Choose the passive voice form of the sentence: 'The manager has reviewed the report.'

options.a: The report has been reviewed by the manager.
options.b: The report is reviewed by the manager.
options.c: The report was reviewed by the manager.
options.d: The report reviews by the manager.

questions.question: Choose the correct modal verb to complete the sentence: 'You ___ finish your homework before you go out.'
